hints: This protocol operates at Layer 3 of the OSI model
It's responsible for routing packets between networks
Its latest version, number 6, uses 128-bit addresses
This protocol provides reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data
It operates at Layer 4 of the OSI model
It uses a three-way handshake to establish connections
This protocol is used to dynamically assign IP addresses to devices on a network
It uses UDP port 67 for server and 68 for client
Its name stands for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
This protocol is used to translate domain names to IP addresses
It operates on UDP port 53 by default
Its name stands for Domain Name System
This networking device operates at Layer 2 of the OSI model
It uses MAC addresses to forward frames within a local network
It helps to reduce network congestion by creating separate collision domains
This networking device operates at Layer 3 of the OSI model
It connects different networks and makes decisions based on IP addresses
It's essential for internet connectivity
This protocol is used to securely access network devices remotely
It encrypts all traffic between the client and server
It typically uses port 22
This protocol is used to transfer files between a client and server
It typically uses port 21 for control and port 20 for data transfer
Its name stands for File Transfer Protocol
This protocol is used to send email messages between servers
It typically uses port 25
Its name stands for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol
This addressing system is used at Layer 2 of the OSI model
It's a 48-bit address typically represented in hexadecimal
It's burned into network interface cards by manufacturers
This protocol is used to find the MAC address of a device given its IP address
It operates at Layer 2 of the OSI model
Its name stands for Address Resolution Protocol
This protocol is used to exchange routing information between gateways
It's a distance-vector routing protocol
Its name stands for Routing Information Protocol
This protocol is used to control message transmission between network devices
It's part of the TCP/IP suite
Its messages include 'Echo Request' and 'Echo Reply'
This technology allows multiple VLANs to be carried over a single network link
It adds a 4-byte header to Ethernet frames
Its IEEE standard is 802.1Q
This protocol prevents loops in switched networks
It creates a tree-like topology with a root bridge
Its IEEE standard is 802.1D
This protocol provides connectionless, unreliable data transfer
It operates at Layer 4 of the OSI model
It's often used for real-time applications like VoIP
This protocol is used to configure and manage network devices remotely
It uses a command-line interface and typically runs over TCP port 23
It sends data in plaintext, making it less secure than SSH
This protocol is used to retrieve email messages from a mail server
It typically uses port 110
Its name stands for Post Office Protocol version 3
This protocol allows email clients to access messages stored on a mail server
It supports operations on multiple mailboxes
Its name stands for Internet Message Access Protocol
This technology allows private networks to communicate securely over a public network
It creates a tunnel between two points
Its name stands for Virtual Private Network
This is a logical subdivision of an IP network
It's created by applying a bitwise AND operation to an IP address and a subnet mask
It allows for more efficient use of IP address space
This protocol is used to synchronize clocks between computer systems
It typically uses UDP port 123
Its name stands for Network Time Protocol
This protocol is used to manage and monitor network devices
It uses the concepts of managers and agents
Its name stands for Simple Network Management Protocol
This protocol is used to resolve IPv6 addresses to MAC addresses
It replaces ARP in IPv6 networks
Its name stands for Neighbor Discovery Protocol
This routing protocol uses link-state technology
It's often used in large enterprise networks
Its name stands for Open Shortest Path First
This protocol suite provides authentication and encryption for IP communications
It's often used in VPNs
Its name stands for Internet Protocol Security
This technology allows multiple devices to share a single public IP address
It modifies network address information in packet headers
Its name stands for Network Address Translation
This is a security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic
It establishes a barrier between trusted internal networks and untrusted external networks
It can be implemented as hardware, software, or both
This protocol is used to configure IPv6 addresses automatically
It doesn't require a server like DHCP
Its name stands for Stateless Address Autoconfiguration
This protocol is used to exchange routing information between autonomous systems
It's the core routing protocol of the Internet
Its name stands for Border Gateway Protocol
